sp.p: Have patience with me—it shall soon be otherwise—soon. (Muttering) Man! why delay? (He looks sorrowfully upon Harry, lifts him up and kisses his forehead) God bless thee my son! (Approaches Arabella, takes her hands and eagerly kisses her fingers) Accept my thanks my dearest wife! (He turns away from her, puts his hands, with trembling emotion, on Harry's head, and utters in agony) God bless thee, my son! (Then, throwing himself into Arabella's arms) Thanks to you, dearest wife! (Now raises his weeping eyes to heaven) Oh, God! these last tears are yet bitterer than I imagined▪

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Robert! what is it you mean to do? Robert, pity my distress!

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Be comforted, Arabella, I go not to India.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: May I trust that you do not?—

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: I do not!—I have yet a friend whom I had shamefully forgotten. To him will I go—from him will I entreat assistance, Pray for me, that he may receive me kindly!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: A friend?—You deceive me?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Ah, Arabella! this hour allows not deception!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Who is he? where is he? why have you never named him to me?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Because in our prosperity, our best friends are often slighted. Yet, fear not; he will receive me kindly; his arms are ever open to the wretched!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Then, go; and your good angel attend you!

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: I go, guided by the angel of love!—Farewel, Arabella!—When next we meet, we shall be happy!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: God grant we may!

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: (Takes both her hands, and shakes them, in great anguish) Till we meet again—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: It will be soon.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: At break of day. (He retires into a corner, wrings his hands unconsciously, makes a severe effort to restrain his tears, undergoes with deep agony the struggle of parting, at last summons up his fortitude, and says) The hardest task is over!—Now to my mother! (Rushes into his mother's room.)

p.stage: (Kneeling, raises her eyes and hands to heaven.)

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What are you doing, Mother?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I pray for your father.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I will also pray for him. (Kneels down by his mother. After some moments, Maxwell rushes out of his mother's room. He is going; but at sight of his wife and child, stops in great agitation. He stands as if rooted to the ground: the muscles of his face are convulsed; his wild, maddened agony dissolves at last into tears. He slowly, and with trembling emotion, lifts up his hands, presses them to his eyes, and reels off.)

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Enter the MOTHER of MAXWELL, grouping her way.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Robert! what means this?—Is no one here?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: (Arising from the posture of prayer) Dear mother, we are here.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: You and my son?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I and Harry.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Where is my son?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Gone to a friend.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: But why was he so deeply affected when he took leave of me?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: He is uneasy in mind, to-day.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Comes bursting into my room—kisses my hand—wets it with his tears—bids me farewel—thanks me for my love—says I shall not want—then runs off before I can even ask him—"Robert, what means this?" —And after all, he goes to a friend!—One should have thought he was going to die!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: (Starts with violent emotion) God forbid!

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Is it right thus to alarm an old, feeble mother? Every limb of me yet shakes with the fright. Come, Harry, lead me back to my chair, that I may recover myself. (Exeunt.)

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: (Stands for some time in amazed and speechless anguish, occasioned by the idea which the old woman's words would have awakened in her mind) No, no—he will not—three other lives, he knows, depehd upon his. (Steps to the table, and turns several leaves in the book upon it, while her looks are fixed on the ground) No— that he never will do. (She strives to compose her mind, sits down at the tambour-frame, and begins to work: but her agitation is renewed; her tears fall; she rises) My tears will spoil my work. (Takes up her knitting-needles; but her arms sink down) Robert! Robert! thou hast unnerved my last strength; I can work no more; I can only pray!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: (Perceiving him, starts convulsively) Ha, Walwyn!

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: (Approaching with a modest and timed air) After eight years of separation, I again see Arabella.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: (Endeavouring to compose herself) Arabella Maxwell is happy to receive an old friend in her house.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: The title of your friend invests me with precious rights.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Your own magnanimity has this day invested you with rights still superior. Accept the thanks which, as a mother and a wife, I owe you.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Arabella's thanks were to me an invaluable prize —had not the offer for which they were made, been disdained!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: That offer was not less a favour. It flowed I know, from the purest motives.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: This testimony gives me pride. But I am conscious, that I have deserved it. (With animation) Yes, Arabella, I am yet entirely such as I was eight years since. Fortune has, indeed, made me rich; but my heart, my soul, are still the same. (He perceives Arabella to be under embarrassment, and moderates his ardour) Pardon, me for having hinted at what is no more to be mentioned. At sight of you, I felt as an old man might do, who meeting with an ancient friend, remembers his spring of life.—And I seemed to myself, for the moment, to grow young again. Ah, no wonder, that your dear image should to me dissolve into a dream, the realities of eight long years: and should, with the efficacy of enchantment bring back the moment, when you last gave me your hand. Your cheeks were then, as now, pale; tears then flowed from your eyes as now.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And I then intreated of you, as I now do to spare me.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
For eight long years have I avoided your presence. The desire of your husband, brings me, this
day, hither, Arabella! Oh know you but the hopes he would teach me to conceive! No, never did the tempter wear a more seductive guise!—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: You allude to a wild idea, which my husband has recently hinted to me.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: I guess that he kept his word!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: You—

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Heard him with amazement.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And let me hope—corrected him—gently—

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Oh! Arabella!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: That sigh—this familiar address!—Should I be mistaken in regard to Walwyn? Should he be capable of trampling on the unfortunate wretch whom he sees writhing at his feet, in the dust▪ then, oh, then would I be compelled to let him look into my heart,—then would I repeat to him those last words which he heard, eight years since, from my lips.—Do you still remember them!

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: They are imprinted on my heart.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Walwyn, I said,—I love you. Fate unites me to another. Were you capable of asking me to tear this bond asunder;—did but one look of your's, invite me to it:—I should lose my last consolation—the consolation of loving and respecting you—On my hand you pronounced the vow of virtue.—

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Which I have ever kept sacred.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Holding your hand, I swore eternal fidelity to my husband. I, too, have kept my oath. I do not say I have found the task a hard one; No: I have found it easy; for, I possess a worthy man. For the first year, I might devote many a secret tear to the remembrance of the sweet dreams of younger years; yet these have been long assuaged by the new feelings of a mother's fondness.—Maxwell's wild fancy of this day, might perhaps have been to me less extravagant, before I was a mother. A childless pair might dare to part! But, now, Walwyn, now, no power on earth can break asunder the bonds of my duty,—No, not the power of love itself.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
I have not interrupted you: for, where I love, I delight to admire. The word escaped; but it came from the heart of a man who knows no wish of which
he can need to be ashamed. Arabella misunderstood me. I listened to your husband, merely to gain time, to sooth the fever of his soul, to save him from the wild phrenzy of despair. His sufferings have awakened within him, powers hitherto unknown to himself, of which the new-born consciousness is pleasing. To sacrifice himself for his wife—is the splendid idea, on which he, at present, delights to gaze till his mind's eye becomes blind to every ray of other hope.—It is for this, that his pride devises so many refined pretensions for refusing the assitance of a friend. These would he scarce resign for the sake of the salvation of his family and himself; for resigning these,—he would lose the idol of his fancy, created by love, nutured by want and despair, raised by disordered nerves to be the tyrant of his soul.—He must be gently and softly led back from the precipice to which he is hurried. As to the night-walker,—we must not call him by his name, but, in silence stretch out our arms, that if he fall, he may sink on the bosom of a friend!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: (Deeply affected, gives him her hand) Excellent Walwyn!—friend in distress!—how could I for a moment, mistake you!—

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: It is only misfortune that excites distrust against the man who once possessed the heart of Arabella!—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And was worthy of possessing it!—

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Wealth could not corrupt a heart sacred to you, I came to concert with you, the means of saving Maxwell. without suffering it to appear the work of my hand. Might we not devise some harmless artifice,—the bequest of some Nabob's fortune,—or the fortunate gaining of some capital prize in the lottery. Pray, assist me to find out something?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Generous man! this tear—

sp.speaker: Jane,
sp.p: (out of breath) Oh madam!—how I am frightened!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: There is a mob gathering in the streets.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: They talk such dreadful things!—They say— they say—that my master—

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: Enter LANDLORD, in a bustling manner.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: There now,—a fine sight,—a fine credit to my house.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: (anxiously) What is it you want, friend?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Want? Why, I want that the corpse be not dragged hither.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: The corpse? Gracious God!

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: (at the same time) Whose corpse?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Don't you know, then? Mr. Maxwell has thrown himself into the Thames.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Oh! too late!

p.stage: (drops upon the ground.)
(kneeling by Arabella, supports her head.)

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: The rent gone to the devil!—

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Perhaps, there may be yet means of recovery.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Of recovery?—to be sure, there are. He is already restored to life!

sp.speaker: Wal. and Jane
sp.p: (at the same time) Does he live?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: As sure as my name is John Hartopp,—he lives—

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Did you hear, dear madam?

p.stage: (Nods.)

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Who saved him?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Why,—I drew him out of the Thames—

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: You, friend?—Pray take this. (Offers his purse)

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Pshaw, pshaw!—such things one don't like to be paid for. Besides, I can't say, after all, that it was I who saved him. For when I had laid him on the bank, he was as dead as a herring. But, there is a society in London, do you see, who will not let a brave fellow drown himself, without a struggle to save him. Some of them were quite at hand. Great gentlemen! God knows who! They instantly seized the body, and continued rubbing warming and blowing, till he opened his eyes.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Whither did they carry him?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: To the house of a rich wine-merchant, three doors from this.—He was the busiest of them all.—He belongs also to the society. (Walwyn exit in haste) God's blessing on the worthy gentleman! When I perceived that life was again stirring in him, I had his house shewn me; for I am vastly fond of bringing good news.— That poor lady on the ground is his wife I dare say?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Yes; his wife.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Well! mistress, do not weep now. There is no more danger. His recovery is sure.

p.stage: (gives her hand)

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: (takes and shakes it heartily) An empty hand, and such a look with it, pleases me better than the gentleman's full purse. I think my girl we should help the good lady on her legs again. (They lift Arabella up, and seat her on a chair.)

p.stage: (Still of a death-like paleness in his countenance —his hair hanging down in disorder,—his looks downcast,—is led by Walwyn to Arabella.)
(Attempting to rise, is unable, but sinks back, and holds out her arms)
(Kneel before her, and with involuntary feebleness, lays his head in her lap)
(Bends sobbing over him.)
(Wipes his eyes with his fingers awkwardly.)
(Stands lost in deep thought; and now and then casts a look on the re-united pair.)
(Lifts up his head, and looks on Arabella with an expression of anguish.)
(Clasps his neck, and joins her cheek to his.)
(Beholds them with strong emotion.)

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: By my soul, it is the man, who this morning tried my load. He perhaps carried heavier than I.—

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: Are you not the same person, who this morning asked my assistance in the tea-garden?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: I am, then, perhaps, in part, tht author of your despair. I have much to atone for. (Taking Walwyn aside) Sir, I know you to be an honest man. May I entirely confide in the truth of what you just now mentioned?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: You may, upon my honour!—

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: (To Maxwell, after a short pause) Sir, my son was yesterday drowned in bathing. I have, this day saved your life. To-day then, has God restored to me a son. You, Sir, must supply the place of my lost child. I adopt you as mine.

p.stage: (Turns to him, kneels, and with ardent emotions of gratitude, stretches out his hands.)

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: I understand—no words—there is no need— your excellent wife will not she be my daughter?

p.stage: (Folds her hands and smiles.)

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: I understand—it is settled—I am not childless.—God forgive my murmurs.

p.stage: (Sinks on her knees beside her husband, clasps him in her arms, and presses him to her heart.)

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Ha! the next load I shall have to carry will be as light as a feather! (The curtain falls.)
